item.name: MySQL cluster node status
item.description: The value is one of 1 (Primary), 2 (Non-Primary) or 3 (Disconnected)

item.name: MySQL status
item.description:
It requires user parameter mysql.ping, which is defined in userparameter_mysql.conf
0 - MySQL server is down 1 - MySQL server is up

item.name: MySQL bytes received per second
item.description:
The number of bytes received from all clients.
It requires user parameter mysql.status[*], which is defined in userparameter_mysql.conf.

item.name: MySQL bytes sent per second
item.description:
The number of bytes sent to all clients.
It requires user parameter mysql.status[*], which is defined in userparameter_mysql.conf.

item.name: Processor load (1 min average per core)
item.description: The processor load is calculates as system CPU load divided by number of CPU cores.

item.name: Processor load (5 min average per core)
item.description: The processor load is calculates as system CPU load divided by number of CPU cores.

item.name: Processor load (15 min average per core)
item.description: The processor load is calculates as system CPU load divided by number of CPU cores.

item.name: CPU idle time
item.description: The time the CPU has spent doing nothing.

item.name: CPU interrupt time
item.description: The amount of time the CPU has been servicing hardware interrupts.

item.name: CPU iowait time
item.description: Amount of time the CPU has been waiting for I/O to complete.

item.name: CPU nice time
item.description: The time the CPU has spent running users' proccess that have been niced.

item.name: CPU softirq time
item.description: The amount of time the CPU has been servicing software interrupts.

item.name: CPU steal time
item.description: The amount of CPU 'stolen' from this virtual machine by the hypervisor for other tasks (such as running another virtual machine).

item.name: CPU system time
item.description: The time the CPU has spent running the kernel and its processes.

item.name: CPU user time
item.description: The time the CPU has spent running users' processes that are not niced.

item.name: Host name
item.description: System host name.

item.name: System information
item.description: The information as normally returned by 'uname -a'.

item.name: Number of logged in users
item.description: Number of users who are currently logged in.

item.name: Available memory
item.description: Available memory is defined as free+cached+buffers memory.

trigger_prototype.name: [HDD.{#DISKNAME}] SMART, Reallocated Sectors Count has been registered 3
[HDD.{#DISKNAME}] SMART critical errors total: {ITEM.LASTVALUE}
trigger_prototype.description: Trigger will be ON for two weeks. If counter is not increasing - Trigger will back to OK

trigger_prototype.name: [HDD.{#DISKNAME}] SMART Spin Retry Count has been registered
[HDD.{#DISKNAME}] SMART UltraDMA CRC Error Count too high: {ITEM.LASTVALUE}. Check cable!
trigger_prototype.description: Low value of this attribute typically indicates that something is wrong with the connectors and/or cables. Disk-to-host transfers are protected by CRC error detection code when Ultra-DMA 66 or 100 is used. So if the data gets garbled between the disk and the host machine, the receiving controller senses this and the retransmission is initiated. Such a situation is called "UDMA CRC error". Once the problem is rectified (typically by replacing a cable), the attribute value returns to the normal levels pretty quick.
